creator: bugzilla@l-i-e.com
text:
I installed okay, and it ran okay, but as soon as I tried to restart, I was
getting errors with what Microsoft says was vendor-specific error code 1.

Starting from a shell (cygwin, actually) yielded:

$ ./httpd.exe -k start
[Mon Nov 27 15:11:11 2006] [error] (OS 2)The system cannot find the file
specified.  : No installed service named "Apache2".

I believe the problem is that I named the service as "Apache2.2" during the
installation, which, upon reading these bug reports, is probably invalid.

The installer shouldn't let me do that.

Or, if I'm reading this stuff wrong and "Apache2.2" is a valid service name, the
startup should not be looking for the default "Apache2" service name, but what I
put in during the installation process.

If all of that is impossible, a better error message somewhere in the error log
file would have been very useful -- as it stands now, you have to be pretty
geeky to dink around with it long enough to get that error message out of a shell.

At any rate, I have to re-install, which is a pain, but will presumably be a
good workaround.

PS
If I just run httpd.exe without the -k start flags, I then have what seems like
a running process, but it crashes as soon as I surf to it...
This may be part of the same problem, or I may be adding another bug report
after I fix the service name.

All of this is by design

"if I'm reading this stuff wrong and "Apache2.2" is a valid service name, the
startup should not be looking for the default "Apache2" service name, but what I
put in during the installation process."

You are, it is.  And I'll investigate if there should be a different default.

In ANY case the workaround is absolutely trivial...

./httpd.exe -k start -n Apache2.2

or if you have a space in a service name

./httpd.exe -k start -n "Apache Service"

although you can use the shorthand and simply omit the spaces.

The running apache as-a-service section in the docs spells this
all out quite clearly.
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text:
All I know is, I didn't do anything THAT weird in installation, and it didn't go
well after I re-started with the GUI tools.

An attempt to re-install didn't seem to prompt me for the service name, so
either it assumed I wanted to keep "Apache2.2", or it's hard-wired or...

Even if I could start it by hand using ... -n Apache2.2, I'd then have to dink
with all the GUI settings to fix that in what seems to be several places, if I
can even find them all.

Put it this way:
When it ends up being easier for an end user to edit the Registry by hand and
rename the key to "Apache2", you know you've got problems.
:-)

I'm seriously re-considering this whole plan, and installing a dual boot on my
employer's computer maybe be easier than dealing with Windows Apache MSI...
creator: bugzilla@l-i-e.com

text:
You reported a bug that Apache 2.2 is an invalid service name and it is valid.

Please leave the bug closed - issues.apache.org is for tracking source code
flaws.

The document you need to read is

  http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/platform/windows.html#winsvc

The GUI tools present the INSTALLED NAME of each of the services, if you
descend into the command line you should learn the command syntax.
